title.rendered: Nothing But The Blood

content.rendered:
Good morning,
Leviticus 17:11, “For the life of the flesh is in the blood, and I have given it to you upon the altar to make atonement for your souls; for it is the blood that makes atonement for the soul.
We understand the power of the blood a life. Anytime someone is bleeding, they try as much as possible to stop the open wound from bleeding why? Because blood is precious, without it in the body, a person can die. What is the work of the blood that makes it precious? Blood carries gases, nutrients and waste products throughout our bodies. Blood also fights infections, heals wounds and performs many other vital functions. There is no substitute for blood. It cannot be made or manufactured.
In the old testament time, there was something about the blood sacrifice. People who sinned gave blood sacrifice of bullocks, sheep and goats to make atonement for their souls. All this pacified God but did not satisfy Him. The blood in the old testament only covered sin until the Lamb of God, who was, who is and is to come came down on the face of the earth wrapped in flesh and blood and offered Himself as a sacrifice by shading His blood precious blood on the cross for the sins of the world. He was the offerer and the offering and He came to take care of what other bloods only covered. While hanging on the cross, a Roman soldier pierced Him on the side and out of His side came water and blood for the sins of world. His blood was so powerful that it screened our sins and washed away our sins. “What can wash away my sin?, nothing but the blood of Jesus; what can make me whole again?, nothing but the blood of Jesus; Oh precious is that flow, that makes me white as snow; no other fount I know, nothing but the blood of Jesus” Not only did the blood take care of what we did, it also took care of what we could have done, what we thought about doing. If it were not for the blood, think about it for a moment, do you know who you would be today? I don’t know who and where I would be today had it not been for the blood. For sure I would be bleeding to death in my sins. The bible makes is clear, “The life of the flesh is in the blood” and the life of the gospel is in the blood. Hebrews 9:22, “…without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness” (NIV). I can now understand why Jesus came as flesh and blood, It was necessary for Him to shed His blood for our sin, the reason He is called the Lamb of God that takes away the sins of the world.
The life of the flesh is in the blood, if the body stops functioning like Abel’s, the blood will still speak out of the body because the blood can speak. And God hears the blood when it speaks. The devil knows the blood is against him and he knows that he has no power over those with the blood of the Lamb marked on the doorpost of their hearts. I remember a another song we sang, “I’m gonna hide right under the blood where the devil can do me no harm”. “There is power, wonder working power in the blood” The blood of Jesus is what ties the blacks and the whites together, the rich and the poor, the young and the old. God does not look at who we are in the natural, He is looking for the color of the blood (RED) of His Son marked on the door post of our hearts.
Choose to apply the blood of the Lamb on the doorpost of your heart. Bring all your activities under the blood, bring your thoughts, actions, destiny, family, friends, colleagues under the blood. God said to the children of Israel, “When I see the blood, I will pass over you”. Meaning that the angel of death, destruction, confusion shall have no power over you when you are under the blood. The devil is extremely afraid of the blood cause the blood is against Him. So hide right under the blood where the devil can do you no harm. I also believe that when God sees the blood on us, He will bless us, minister to us and encourage us. Rev 12:11, “And they overcame him by the blood of the Lamb and by the words of their testimony“, The blood of the Lamb is highly recommended.
Blessings
Ev

title.rendered: Jesus Christ is God

content.rendered:
Good morning,
John 1:1, “In the beginning was the Word, and the ﻿Word was ﻿with God, and the Word was ﻿God. ﻿2﻿ ﻿He was in the beginning with God”
In as much as Matthew’s writing was to establish Jesus Christ as King, John on the other hand took time to pen that Jesus was(is) God. Genesis 1:1, begins by saying, “In the beginning God…”, then here comes John helping us understand that Jesus was there when creation took place and not only that, He was involved in the creation process.
John wrote to convince his readers of Jesus’ true identity as the incarnate God-Man whose divine and human natures were perfectly united into one person who was the prophesied Christ (“Messiah”) and Savior of the world. Today people think of Jesus as a good man who walked on the face of this earth many years ago, some also believe he was a good teacher not forgetting a prophet. The moment you mention that Jesus Christ is God, this is where they disagree with you. We need to understand that He was more than just a man, a good man, a teacher or a prophet, He was and is God.
Jesus, the second Person of the Trinity. The Word, as the Second Person of the Trinity, was in intimate fellowship with God the Father throughout all eternity. Yet, although the Word enjoyed the splendors of heaven and eternity with the Father (Is. 6:1–13; cf. 12:41; 17:5), He willingly gave up His heavenly status, taking the form of a Man, and became subject to the death of the cross. Philippians 2:6, “Who, although being essentially one with God and in the form of God [possessing the fullness of the attributes which make God God], did not think this equality with God was a thing to be eagerly grasped or retained” (Amplified Version). Just because He is the second Person in the Trinity does not make Him less equal with God the Father.
Trinity is God the Father, God the Son and God the Holy Spirit, all three are one fitting in the God Head, and 1John 5:6, tells us “6 This is He who came by water and blood—Jesus Christ; not only by water, but by water and blood. And it is the Spirit who bears witness, because the Spirit is truth. 7 For there are three that bear witness in heaven: the Father, the Word (Jesus), and the Holy Spirit; and these three are one“. To continue establishing Jesus as God, Upon seeing and touching Jesus hands where the nails went through and His side where the Roman soldier pierced, the doubting Thomas also confirms to us that Jesus is God, John 20:28, “Thomas said to him, “My Lord and my God!”
Why is the understating and establishing Jesus as God very important? There are people who believe in some Jesus but not the true Jesus represented in the scriptures and without us understanding the true Jesus, we cannot be saved. Question to us all, have we had a wrong understanding of who Jesus truly is? Has been presented to us by some preacher or teacher in a way that is not revealed in the scripture?. Let’s pray and study the Word to have a better understanding of who Jesus is and that is, He is God. He is not a created being as some religions believe, He is not an angel, He is not the brother of the devil as some believe. Read entire 1John 5, John has a lot to tell us. John 1:1, “In the beginning was the Word, and the ﻿Word was ﻿with God, and the Word was ﻿God. ﻿2﻿ ﻿He was in the beginning with God”
Blessings
Evans

title.rendered: If It Cost Him, It Will Cost You, Part 2

content.rendered:
Good morning,
2Samuel 24:1-25, “…I will not sacrifice to the Lord my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing” (NIV)
Vs. 15, “So the Lord sent a plague upon Israel from the morning till the appointed time. From Dan to Beersheba seventy thousand men of the people died” Seventy thousand died for one man while one Man died for over 6billion people. What a sacrifice when you think about it, of late I have talked more about sin, Christ, His death and salvation and it’s because our eyes are being opened to see that this was no cheap sacrifice yet at times we treat it casually. 1Peter 1:18&19, “Knowing that you were not redeemed with corruptible things, like silver or gold… but with the precious blood of Christ, as a Lamb without blemish and without spot”.
When God brought the plague, David now saw himself not just as a sinner but a transgressor. Here is the difference from the way I have heard it, sin is missing the mark, transgressing is way far over missing the mark. At first David saw what he did as sin but when he saw the consequences, he saw himself as a transgressor and Vs. 17, “…and he said, “surely I have sinned, and I have done wickedly; but these sheep (Lamb), what have they done? Let Your hand, I pray, be against me…”. This did blow my mind cause it’s becoming real and personal to see that someone else has to suffer because not only did I miss the mark, I went beyond missing the mark and deserve that horrific punishment. Christ did not deserve what He went through but because of my sins and your sins, He took the horrific punishment for us. It’s how David saw himself at that point that allowed God to now give him grace.
Vs. 18, “And Gad (prophet) came that day to David and said to him, “Go up, erect and altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite”. Good God of mercy, fall into His hands and He will show you how you’ve transgressed. He will show you the price for it and who paid for it and how you react at that point will lead you to the next move. So David has just had PEACE WITH GOD and he is instructed to erect an altar to the Lord. The man he meets offers him a threshing floor free of charge to build an altar but he refuses completely to take it even after much persuasion to have it for free. He insists on buying it by saying, in Vs. 24, “…I will not sacrifice to the Lord my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing” (NIV)”. The first opening verses and this verse troubled me for sometime cause I was trying to understand what the Lord was doing. How come the Lord did not just forgive him like he had prayed the first time?, here is what the Spirit of God tipped me on, David would have not appreciated the forgiveness like he did it after being shown how far he missed the mark and some people who had to pay for it. Now what sign of gratitude is he giving back to God?, if it cost You to forgive me, I will not bring to You what cost me nothing why? because just like the woman who washed Jesus feet with oil and wiped it with her hair in Luke 7, she had been forgiven much and because of it, she was sacrificing the best, Luke 7:47, “Therefore I say to you, her sins, which are many, are forgiven, for she loved much. But to whom little is forgiven, the same loves little“. Alabaster box carried precious ointment, very expensive. The box was suppose to hold even the fragrance for even the fragrance was expensive. What she did was take that expensive oil and sacrificed it to the Lord because of how she had been forgiven and so was David and so will you and I.
The only reason why both could sacrifice is because of the sacrifice someone else made for them and all they were doing was showing a heart of gratitude to the One who forgave them. With this in mind, it’s not anymore about we want, but what He wants. It’s about Lord what can I do to show you as a sign of gratitude. It will cost you money to bless a ministry that will reach out to many people, it will cost you time, much prayers, stepping out of your comfort zone, reaching out to the lost why? because You love Him. Lord it did cost You therefore it will cost me too for I have seen the sacrifice to appreciate cost.
Blessings
Evans

title.rendered: If It Cost Him, It Will Cost You, Part 1

content.rendered:
Good morning,
2Samuel 24:1-25, “…I will not sacrifice to the Lord my God burnt offerings that cost me nothing” (NIV)
Failing God scares me to death. I can fail God by sinning (breaking His commandments) or neglecting to do what He requires of me. I am scared of becoming a lukewarm and compromising Christian simply because I love the Lord and because of what He has done in my life. I will show Him gratitude through my life style. I have also sacrificed a lot to be where I am and to be used of Him. It’s hard work to grow and easy for something growing to die fast.
David was known as a man after God’s own heart at the same time, he had so many flaws in his life. He’s secret of success comes from continuously running back to God and repenting every time he messed up. He was quick to repent of his sins. On the above mentioned chapter, he performed census when he should have not for I believe through it, it was leading to pride. In 2Samuel 24:10, “And David’s heart (conscience) condemned (accused) him after he had numbered the people”. The first thing that happens when we do wrong is that our conscience reveals to us our state even before someone else does, the question is, what shall a man do with that conviction? hide it? cover it up? try to justify it?. Immediately he sinned in the same verse 10, it says “…so David said to the Lord, “I have sinned greatly in what I have done; but now, I pray, O Lord, take away the iniquity of Your servant, for I have done foolishly“. His sin was primarily vertical and he had to square it with heaven for Proverbs 15:3, “The eyes of the Lord are in every place, beholding the evil and the good”. This was a man who knew he couldn’t escape from the presence of God, he tells us about it in Psalm 139 .
The Lord God Almighty sends a message to David in vs. 11 through prophet Gad with three options of punishment to pick from 1. seven years of famine in the land, 2. three months of fleeing from his enemies and 3. three days of plague in his land. Watch this closely, the first two look severe and would mean men would also be involved in the sense that if there was famine, they could look to other men to get food, second, if left in the hands of the enemy, that would mean destruction for him. Guess what option he picked, option three which is God sent. Listen to why he picked that option, 2Samuel 24:14, “And David said to Gad, “I am in great distress. Please let us fall into the hand of the Lord, for His mercies are great; but do not let me fall into the hand of man“. Yes I have failed and sinned against God and I deserve punishment, instead of running away in time of trouble, I would rather fall into the hands of God that was David’s attitude and prayer. Nature does not forgive, man forgive some times, God forgive always, whose hands would you rather fall in? Even when you have failed, don’t run away, fall into the hands of God and not in the hands of man. Yes he spoke to the Lord about what he did, the Lord is bringing him to a place where he can see that what he did was very serious therefore he deserves punishment. 70 thousand men are about to die because of one man’s disobedience and that is what Christ also did for us, the Man paid for our disobedience by being punished for the sins He did not commit. It’s the plague of sin which brought the death of Christ on the cross.
Hebrews 10:31, “It’s a fearful thing to fall into the hands of the living God“, Does God condone sin? look at the seventy men that died and look at the cross where His Son died and you will understand that God hates sin. I know where I have failed, I’m falling back to His hands. To continue, good weekend and remember Monday is holiday for us here.
Blessings
Evans

title.rendered: Walking With The Lord

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Genesis 5:24, “And Enoch walked with God: and he was not; for God took him”

We struggle in our walk with the Lord daily, there are days of trying times, winning times, discouraging times and even failing times. Times when you don’t feel like praying like you should or reading the word and even witnessing like you should. Life goes through different seasons and each season has a way to prep you for the next season. Seasons change from time to time and as human beings, we have learn to adapt in different seasons using the necessary tools suitable for that season so that in the long run you can move to the next season. We don’t quit functioning because we are in the middle of winter, we continue to function without using the same strategy we used to function during summer time. As believers we also have seasons and every season presents it’s case in a different way and we got to learn through the word of God on how to adapt and function in these seasons without retreating or surrendering for they will always be there. Our seasons may be different but we all have seasons. Seasons of dry periods, seasons of spiritual prosperities, seasons of blessings, seasons of change to name a few. Every believer should know the season in which they are in, maintain their composure, learn everything that God would want you to learn in that season and trust God for the next season. How you deal with one season will definitely affect how you will deal with the next season. Someone said, “if you are in a tough season, don’t pray God get me out of it but rather pray, Lord what do you want me to learn from it”.

In my text, Cain killed his brother Abel in Genesis 4 and God told him of what would become of him, Gen 4:16&17 says, “The Cain went out from the presence of the Lord and dwelt in the land of Nod”. Meanwhile Adam knew his wife again, and she bore a son and named him Seth, His name means “For God has appointed another seed for me instead of Abel“. They had been in a season of mourning for the lost of Abel their youngest son and that season was gone and God gives them a substitute to replace what they lost. As you read the genealogy of Adam, to Seth, you will see that many generations passed before we are told about a man by the name of Enoch. Something interesting in Genesis 4:26, “And as for Seth, to him also a son was born; and he named him Enosh. the men began to call on the name of the Lord“, I believe that from Seth’s descendants, man began to come back to the Lord. We are not told much about Enoch all we know of is that he walked with God for 300 years (Gen 5:22). If there was anything that was recorded about Enoch is the fact that he walked with God in other words he had pleased the Lord in his life. He must have been a worshiper and faith bearer, the bible says in Heb 11:6, “for without faith, it is impossible to please Him…”. If there be anything that we can use to remember this man was that He walked with God and he was not which is to say that he did not die for God took him. Many people in the bible had something about them, and God to favored them. Abraham was known as the Father of faith and a friend of the Lord, David known as a man after God’s own heart, Noah was known as the man who worked with God and many more and even though they also had their own failures and weakness, they maintained what we still talk about today about them. They had their different seasons but they did not give up.

I want us to understand that their walks were not easy but they were determined to be the best they could by God’s help. Growing and walking with the Lord is not easy and for a man to walk with the Lord 300 years faithfully is something that I wouldn’t take lightly. Enoch had only one important thing he left behind and that is the testimony that he had walked, pleased, served, worshiped the Lord. In as much as we have our own seasons and got to deal with them, we can a build a testimony that through it all, we walked with the Lord. A testimony that even the unbelievers can see, a testimony that stands through the trials and fire. Job had this kind of testimony that though he went through trying seasons, he still maintained his integrity. How I pray that we will walk with the Lord every single day regardless of the season or the cycles. We got to be willing to maintain that walk for it’s all we’ve got, let’s build testimonies that speaks even in our absence. I choose to walk with You Lord so help me.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Miracles Still Happens

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Luke 10:17, “The seventy-two returned with joy and said, “Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name.” 18He replied, “I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven. 19 I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you. 20However, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.” (NIV)

I love when miracles unfold right before my eyes. What I least expected to happen out of nowhere happens and all I can say, “God is in this, He is the reason I see the miracle unfold right before my eyes. There are those miracles that God does them and you see the results and then there are those miracles that He does through you. One of the miracles and the greatest miracles I have seen the Lord do through me is in going on the streets to witness to the lost. I am learning over and over again that rarely do miracles happen in safe grounds, where everything is normal. They happen when you step out of the ordinary in obedience and you say, “Lord, it’s not by my ABILITY that miracles will happen, it’s by my AVAILABILITY that you will cause miracles to happen”

The bible says, Jesus appointed 70 people and sent them two by two into every city He was about to go to. Luke 10:2, “He told them, “The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few. Ask (pray) the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field”. He appointed 70 people not to sit down and enjoy His presence but equipped them and sent them out to the field. He told them of the harvest that was plentiful and the fact that there were few laborers working in the harvest field. See harvest don’t just happens, there have to be laborers in the field who are available to harvest what the Master has prepared for harvest. Anyway, they went under the power of Jesus and they performed great miracles They came back to Jesus with reports of what happened in the harvest field, they said, “Lord, even the demons submit to US in YOUR name.”. Miracles were happening that even the demons were submitting to them in Jesus name and then Jesus said to them, “I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you”, God has given His called the power to do great and mighty things but the greatest miracle they needed to rejoice over more was not that the demons were subject to them but rejoice that your names are written in heaven”. These included the names of those people who they had shared the gospel with and received it by faith.

There is not greater miracle than to see a person lost in sin get humbled by the gospel and he cries out, what must I do to be saved. I have seen the miracles of healing, financial provisions, restoration but none of them speak volumes like the miracle of seeing a lost soul turning to Jesus right before your eyes as the Lord works the miracle through as you share the gospel with them. I encounter such miracles every time I step out on the streets to share the gospel. Last week, my friend AJ and I were on the streets sharing the gospel, we stopped at haircut shop that had just been opened, met the owner (Bruno) a big Italian dude, very sarcastic in his talk, cared nothing about where he will spend eternity. As I gently began to share with him the law, righteousness, judgment, hell, heaven, the cross etc, all of a sudden, the Holy Spirit captured this man’s heart, humbled him, convicted him while he stood to listen to the whole gospel. Even when one of his customers came in, he asked him to give him a few minutes to hear this important message. Is that a miracle or what? I could tell you of a young man Miguel who I shared with yesterday. He was about to play basketball with his friends but then stopped to listen to the whole gospel. Even when his friends told him he would not play anymore if he did not come immediately, he said, “this is too important to play” and he did not play. I have so many stories of miracles after miracles where I spoke to people on the streets who are hard cores, loud mouthed, blasphemous, God hater’s and then see their hearts softens and they become humble, got convicted, stop justifying themselves and received the good news. And their response, “I got to make things right with God” and later be thanked for being out there to share the gospel. We may wait forever for such people to come to church to hear the gospel, we have to go out there and harvest them for Jesus. He has prepared them as ripe harvest just waiting to be harvested.

Brothers and sisters, only God can perform such a miracle but only when we are available to be used of Him. I am always scared going out there but after it’s been said and done I always come back rejoicing. Heaven rejoices over the miracle of a lost soul being saved and you and I can be part of that miracle. If you want to see miracles, step out of the boat like Peter and walk on water by faith and let God use you for His glory.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Confess What You Believe

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Romans 10:10, “For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness and with the mouth confession is made unto salvation”.

With time, things have changed. Men’s beliefs have shifted from what is known to be true to what they perceive to be the truth. If I believe this and you don’t, that is up to me for what is right for me might not be right for you. What one person accepts might not be what the other person will accept. Absolute truths are fought to be relative. “You stick to your opinions and I will stick to mine” is what we hear. Sadly enough, many have followed and accepted beliefs, doctrines, lifestyles because they were already there and therefore they called them truth without actually digging in to find out.

In 1Samuel 17, entitled David defeats Goliath is a very familiar story. It’s a story that has been taught in Sunday schools, people have read about it over and over of how God gave victory to David through a sling shot over a big giant. I want us to look at his preparation that ultimately I may link it with the top theme verse. vs. 1Sam 17:34, “But David said to Saul, “Your servant used to keep his father’s sheep and when a lion or a bear came and took a lamb out of the flock, I went after it and struck it, and delivered the lamb from it’s mouth…”. Here is David doing preparation by recalling how God had given him victory over the lion and the bear while he was just but a boy. He had believed God for greater things even in his youth and standing before a king and reciting his past victories were not foolish to him. 2Tim 1:12, “For the which course I also suffer these things: nevertheless I am not a shamed: for I know whom I have believed and I am persuaded that He is able to keep that which I have committed unto Him against that day”. He knew that he had to suffer rejection and at times fear but he concluded that he will not be a shamed to share what God had done in his life why, because he was persuaded. Persuade means to convince or win over. Doubt and fear may have tried to rise up in his life, but then what God had done in life had persuaded him to trust Him even more and he was ready to commit this next challenge to Him. Romans 10:10, “For with the heart man believeth unto righteousness. One can only believe in his/her own heart in other words having faith unto righteousness that can be interpreted as virtue, morality, decency, uprightness etc and where does all this come from?, from the Lord.

1Samuel 17:45&46 “Then David said unto the Philistine, “You come to me with a sword, with a pear, and with javelin. But I come to you in the name of the Lord of host, the God of the armies of Israel, whom you have defied. This day the Lord will deliver you into my hands, and I will strike you and take your head from you. And this day I will give carcasses of the camp of the philistine to the birds of the air and the wild beast of the earth, that all the earth may know that there is a God in Israel“. No one can make such a confession if they don’t believe in the person whom they are introducing as their source of strength. David knew where the Lord had brought him from and what the Lord had done and he was persuaded that it wasn’t the last time God would help him. He therefore confessed his belief (trust, faith) in God ability to back His confession. Romans 10:10, “….with the mouth confession is made unto salvation”. It’s not the stone that killed Goliath, it’s the confession David made that destroyed him inside. All the stone did was finish what the words began.

You can believe which is great but confession goes beyond believing for confession is an absolute statement to show that one will practice what they believe. One’s confession is a total agreement with what has been said and supports it 100%. I believe in healing, I will confess healing; I believe in salvation, I will confess salvation; I believe that the Lord protects me everyday, I will confess that the Lord protects me every day. The devil will try and plant doubt inside to overtake the trust, your confession will begin to pump boldness and courage to fight back. I believe that as David was speaking these words, his boldness, courage and trust increased for there is power when we speak the truth. The woman with the issue of blood kept on pumping faith, boldness and courage through her confession, “If I may but touch the hem of His garment, I know I will be made whole”. She did not say it ones, she kept on repeating it to herself over and over. Our confession might need repetition until no doubt is left within. This morning I tell the enemy, you come to me in the name of depression, fear, doubt, confusion, weariness but I come to you in the name that is above every name Jesus. With the mouth confession is made unto salvation. You want to be an overcomer? begin to confess what you believe according to the word of God which is the absolute truth

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Disciplined To Protect, Part 2

content.rendered:
Good morning,

James 1:17, “Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above and comes down from the Father of light, with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning“

We looked father and son with gifts but when they were in foreign land, they could not protect and defend their gifts because of their selfish reasons. If you take a closer look at what I shared on, you will see that I talked about tangible gift, external gift. Today let’s look at some people who received internal gifts and how they were later manifested externally and how they handled them.

When you talk about Sarah, Samson’s mother, Hannah, Elizabeth and Rachel you will find that they had one thing in common, they were barren at one time in their lives. The state of being barren means one is in no position of producing offspring. A barren woman in the old days and in some societies was considered cursed and rejected by their tribesmen. A woman with the ability to have children especially boys was considered a blessed woman and respected because of the fruits in her womb. And we see about 5 women with the same problem, Genesis 11:30, “But Sarah was barren; she had no child, Genesis 29:31″…but Rachel was barren”, 1Samuel 1:5, “But to Hannah he would give a double portion, … although the Lord had closed her womb (barren)”, Judges 13:2, “…whose name was Manoah; and his wife was barren and had no children”, Luke 1:7, “But they had no child, because Elizabeth was barren”. What a state to be in, everyone is nurturing their babies, these few women had no babies to call their own. A lot of “I wish” must have ran through their minds, questions as to why would a loving God leave them in conditions such as this. Some had rivals provoking them over and over again. They had everything according to man’s standards but not satisfied. They must have wondered, where is every good gift and every perfect gift that the Father sends from above?. Have you ever wondered and asked God how come everyone gets their gift but you? You ask, what is wrong with me that I don’t have it? Everyone seem to be benefiting from their gifts but me, I have people provoking me in different ways but are You are quiet not saying anything. I have called on You to do something about my situation but not a word. Ever felt that way?

The Almighty God is a God of time, He who invented time, keeps time. The bible says that He makes all things beautiful in His time. When He begins to do things, you begin to see why the gifts were delayed but not denied. These women had needs and when they least expected to be visited, that is the time God visited them. God visited them at a time when what He wanted to do was really needed. Through promise, God gave them gifts by opening their wombs to give birth and each of them reacted differently. God’s promises are ye and amen and when you list expect it and when you feel you are not qualified to have it, that is when He comes to do it, why?, because He has the ability to do it when no man can do it. Ordinary women receiving extraordinary gifts. Their one gift made them to be known and greater things did their children do. Look at some of the women who had their wombs opened, they had so many children but they were not used in a mighty way like the children of the mothers who were once barren. Rachel had Joseph, Hannah had Samuel, Elizabeth had John the Baptist, Sarah had Isaac and the list continues. What they received were not of man but of God. The grounds which could not bring forth, by God’s grace, they brought forth. I look at many years ago I was also barren in many areas, I wanted to be used of God but because I did not have the gift of Anointing in me through the help of the Holy Ghost, I watched people and even guys of my age do exploits for the Kingdom. Later when God visited me, in my unworthiness, He entrusted me with the spiritual gifts of praying, teaching, preaching and leading. An ordinary man receiving extraordinary gifts. God’s gifts are for a reason and not for a season!

I wondered what would cause God to use these ordinary women and this is what I came up with and also looking at my life. First, they were humble women, 1Peter 5:6, “Humble yourselves therefore under the mighty hand of God, that He may exalt you in due season”, their humility caused them to be exalted. Second, they were willing to receive the gift even after being given tough conditions to abide by. Third, they were available to be used to bring forth servants of God. Fourth, they were faithful to carry these babies in their wombs and brought them forth and natured the babies till God was ready to use them. They were disciplined to protect the seeds in their wombs without aborting them. I know people who have aborted the gifts that were deposited in their wombs. Having a gift in you requires work to keep it alive and in shape. Pregnant women don’t just sit and wait to deliver, they take good care of themselves, they watch what they eat, where they go, who they hang out with for what they are carrying is precious. I also know people who want something to be deposited in their barren wombs but they do not want to be humble, willing, available and faithful. I wouldn’t pray for a gift I’m not willing to sacrifice for. Any gift comes with a responsibility therefore my prayer everyday is that Lord I want to be disciplined to protect every gift you have invested in me for I do not want to loose any gift. I will humble myself, be willing, available and faithful, deposit more gifts. I will do whatever it takes to protect them how about you?

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Disciplined To Protect, Part 1

content.rendered:
Good morning,

James 1:17, “Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above and comes down from the Father of light, with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning“

We love receiving gifts. Gifts are things bestowed voluntary and without compensation. It’s the act, right, or power of giving. Simply a thing given freely. Gifts are good things you are hoping to be received with joy. How many times do we struggle to run a round to find that good gift that we hope it will make happy whoever we give it to? The moment you sense a sign of dissatisfaction, you feel disappointed. We get gifts mostly on certain occasions. If you gave someone a gift, the first question that might run through their mind is, “What is the occasion?”. God does not give us gifts based on occasions, it’s based on His love for us. Every good gift and every perfect gift is from above, what are some of these gifts, eternal life, Holy Ghost, hope, peace, joy, strength, courage, wisdom, life, marriage, job, ministry, calling, kids, home, health, confidence you name it are gifts from above. All these gifts have two things in common, they are good and they are from above. Psalm 124:8, “Our help (gift) is in the name of the Lord, Psalm 121:1, “I will lift up my eyes unto the hills, from whence come my help (gift). Already we have established that gifts are things bestowed and not earned and if you look at your life closely. For a minute forget about what you’ve not received and concentrate on the gifts you’ve received. See if you ever qualified for any of those gifts? Every gift needs to be protected by all means.

Let me introduce two men, very much related, father and son who received gifts from God but something happened that I will touch on. In Genesis 12:10- Abram (Abraham), he was 75 years old married to Sarai (Sarah). Abram had received a gift from heaven by the name of Sarai and even in her old age, she still looked young and beautiful, here is what the bible says about her. Genesis 12:11, “And it came to pass when he was close to Egypt, that he said to Sarai his wife, “Indeed I know that you are a woman of beautiful countenance“. I believe the gift God gives, He will preserve, nature and care for. So Abram thought the Egyptians might kill him for his wife. He then convinced Sarai to pretend to be his sister. Here is a man who was suppose to protect his wife from anyone but because he cared more about his self image, he neglects the task to protect the gift bestowed upon him. He cares more about what people will think than what he knows is right. He is selfish for he is not taking into consideration that the men will try to lay their hands on Sarai. It’s like saying that as long as we are in the church I will let everyone know that you are a gift to me but the moment we are out there, I will change the way we relate. Sounds like something very familiar, as long as I am in the church, let every one see Jesus in me but the moment I’m out there, I may not want to be identified with Him cause what will people think?. Abram almost lost his wife because Pharaoh fell for her but God protected Abram’s gift from the vultures by bringing calamities in the family of Pharaoh until he released her without touching her. Thought Abram would learn his lesson but not quite, Genesis 20:1, “And Abraham journey from there to the south, and dwelt between Kadesh and Shur….vs. 2, “Now Abraham said of Sarah his wife, “she is my sister”. And Abimelech King of Gerah sent and took Sarah“. For the second time he introduces Sarah after their names changed as his sister. I’m wondering, what could have been going through Sarah’s mind? “my husband who is suppose to be my protector and defender is not doing his job, instead he keeps on presenting me as someone I’m not”. Once again God protects Sarah from the hand of king Abimelech by sending a dream to stop him from sinning. Abraham almost had two kings sin because of his stand but God stopped the kings from sinning and protected Sarah once again. Then here comes his son after many years in king Abimelech’s kingdom. Isaac was married to Rebekah who the bible says was beautiful to behold. Genesis 26:6, “So Isaac dwelt in Gerar, vs. 7 And the men of the place asked for his wife. And he said, She is my sister, “for he was afraid to say, “she is my wife”, because he thought, “lest the men of the place kill me for Rebekah”. Even in the case of Isaac, God protected Rebekah from being touched by other men.

What I’m I saying? Good gifts ought to be protected at all cost and by all means regardless of time or place. Man of integrity will talk highly about their wives wherever they go, they will defend them, they will protect regardless of the cost. They will not be a shamed of who they are. I believe that when you have received a gift regardless of what it is, you will take good care for it for you do not want to disappoint the Giver. Could it be possible that many don’t get more gifts because they are careless with what they received? The more disciplined we become to protect that which is bestowed upon us, the more we can be trusted with more. Be disciplined to protect every gift bestowed upon you.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Gold Tried By Fire

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Job 13:15, “Though He slay me yet I will trust Him, I will maintain mine own ways before Him”. Job 23:10, “He knows the way that I take, after He has tried me, I shall come forth as gold”.

There are a couple of things I tend to battle, as time goes by, you will also agree with me that you battle some if not all of them. I fear conflicts by all means, adversities is another one, I do fear rejection, I fear not being able to make it and I fear failing. Anyone with me in this? I don’t like being in positions of not knowing what to do even when there is something that can be done. Not seeing something that I should have seen that someone comes to point it out. If it happens frequently, you will feel frustrated. I have come to discover that if I did something the wrong way, it might take me several attempts to make it right but that would mean more mistakes before it becomes right.

Let me cover adversities today as I believe adversities are good for us. Here are some words related to adversities, hardships, difficulty, danger, harsh conditions, hard times, misfortune. I’m not saying that adversities are nice, they are like medication good for our health if we let them be. One preacher said, “Many have never allowed problems to work for them” and this is true, instead of it working for them, it’s working them, destroying them. Romans 8:28 always come into perspective for it works whether on good times or bad times. If there was a way to avoid adversities, I would be the first one to avoid them for it’s not fun yet it works for our good. Job tells us in Job 13:15, “Though He slay me yet I will trust Him, I will maintain mine own ways before Him”. Job did not request for adversities but he faced them and it made Him stronger, it taught him how to trust more, taught how to react, and taught him that God is the Boss and he is nothing without God. Adversities taught him to trust and maintain his ways before God. He also says in Job 23:10, “He knows the way that I take, after He has tried me, I shall come forth as gold”. What a bold statement in times of adversities, some would have complained and cursed God. Job understood that God knew the way His servant takes and that is the path of purity, faith, trust, humility, confidence in Him and what he is saying is if God can give him grace and strength to go through this test, ge will come forth as gold. They say that for the gold to be purified and all the other elements to be taken off, it has to be taken through the fire, why? because the gold can survive the fire when the other elements will be consumed in it. The other elements don’t turn into gold, they get out of the way for gold to be seen.

There are four ways to respond to adversities, you can Maximize it, Minimize it, Advertise it or Analyze it. Maximizing it is exaggerating and putting more into it than what is already there. Being destroyed by something that hasn’t even happened yet or something that has just started. For example, someone could have a headache to them that could be too big, the way they talk about it could make it extremely big and impossible to deal with. This is because they are putting more into it than what is already there. Maximizing it is trying to understand it with a lot of why did this happen to me? what did I do wrong? why me?. Minimizing is the attitude of not trying to make a big deal out of it. It looks terrible but it’s not that bad as I thought or suppose. The problem with minimizing it is trying to cover it up when you got to deal with it. Advertise it is very lethal for you want the whole world to know you are dealing with problems. The way you appear, the way you talk, the way you act is advertising to everyone that are dealing with stuff hoping someone will join you in your pity party. Analyzing it is the best way to go about it. This is extracting useful information from it and knowing that things don’t just happen. There are things we got ourselves into that brought adversities and now we got to learn from our mistakes so that we don’t have to repeat them again. There are things that happen that we have no control over and yet there are things that we could learn from. Job did not do anything wrong but the accuser of the brethren approached God and said Job’s reason for serving God was because of what he had. Just to say something, God does not try anyone, He may allow but He is not the author of it. In this case, God allowed Satan to try Job but to a limit. The limit was to take everything that he had but not His life. God will allow but He will control the thermostat. He will not give us more than we can handle. Job took the time to analyze why he had to go through adversities and he got useful information that sustained him. Some of the things he learnt, never put trust in man, you can loose what you have but not God, you can truly know who your friends are, you can maximize the faith inside of you, you can be trusted with something that would kill someone else, you can learn to serve others better cause you know what people go through and many more, you can have a greater testimony. Instead of you and I crying out, “Lord get me out of this”, our cry should be, “Lord, what can I learn from this?”.

When you and I know that adversities are good for us, you can be like David in 1Samuel 30:6, “…But David strengthened (encouraged) himself in the Lord his God”. David had face so many adversities in 1Samuel 30 and his soldiers were about to stone him yet he took the liberty to encourage and strengthen himself and the soldiers who wanted to stone him. When we all face them at any time, cry if you must but let it not wear you down, encourage yourself in the Lord. Avoid maximizing, trying to minimize it, stop advertising adversities and start analyzing it why? because you will have the confidence to face it claiming Romans 8:28, “And we know that all things work together for good to them that love God, to them who are called according to His purpose”

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: From Gathering To Assembling

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Psalms 133,”Behold how good and pleasant it is for brethren to dwell together in unity”

There is a huge difference between gathering and assembling, Mat 18:20, “For where two or three are gathered in my name, there am I in the midst of them”. Looking at this verse, we see a progression that will give us the complete picture of what it means. The verse begins with “gathered” then “in His name” meaning that we have one God, when we gather in His name, we become assembled. There is no way we are going to share one God without bumping into each other and learning to walk, work and worship together. Many have gathered but have not assembled and so everything has become a routine. About five years ago I bought an entertainment center for my living room, the whole thing was in the box even though I saw the picture of what to expect, that is not how it came. They were pieces gathered in a big box. Every piece in that box was significant starting from the sideboards to the small nuts. The interesting thing about the whole thing is that all the pieces were gathered in the box but not assembled for it to be a unit. We came in as different pieces ultimately that God would make us a unit. Where God brings unity in diversity. Each piece is significant and has to be fitted in it’s designed place to complete the unit, no one will ever know what the Master had in mind when He brought each piece together. Fitting the pieces together calls for work.

1 Cor 12:12, “For the body is one, and hath many members, and all the members of that one body, being many are one body: so is Christ” We all have different gifts. My gifts may not be your gifts and the gifts that you have may not be my gifts but these gifts are used to edify one another for the glory of God. The body has different parts, the hands, legs, mouth, ears and the rest. They all have different functions but they cannot operate effectively without each of them. One may be very small and the big one will need it and so the bible puts it clearly “Behold how good and pleasant it is for brethren to dwell together in unity”. The verse shows us that it’s good for brethren and not just anyone to stand work together. If it had just stopped at dwelling together, then we all could be one room and still be the same as we were by ourselves, when completed with the word “In Unity”, it opened our eyes to see that there is more to gathering and that it to be assembled.

Have you discovered the gifts that God has placed in you? these are gifts given to us to minister to one another that we may no longer just gather but assemble.
The moment you begin to use your gifts to reach out to someone, if they were in pieces, your presence and what you have to do will help assemble them or put them back together. I know I have the gift of prayer, encouraging and preaching, I want to use all these to reach out to other people because the more I use them, the more I’m put together myself and the more I get united with the people I reach out to. I don’t have the gift of singing though I love to sing, God will send someone else to minister to me in that area. When was the last time you used your gifts to reach out to someone else? when was the last time you desired not just to gather but help assemble? You can make a difference because of what God has given you, be faithful with it.

No one saw this coming so it’s a huge blow to her family and for us who worked closely with her. Pray for peace and strength as the family tries to cope up with her death.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Sold Out For Jesus, Part 2

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Matthew 16:18, “And I also say to you that you are Peter, and on this rock I will build My church, and the gates of Hades shall not prevail against it”

As I mentioned yesterday, you can be defined and not be there yet. Often times we rejoice over the definition. Rejoicing over who we will be until we hit the process. David was anointed (defined) next king but he was not told the process. If he knew Saul would be after his life and so are many enemies for the next 17 years before making it to the throne, maybe he would have re thought the king thing. I love definition, it’s the process that either breaks you or make you and that scares me.

Definition is followed by the process and the process is the tough part. Peter has a definition, the process is to bring that definition to pass. We can still see his failures yet Christ does not give up on him. The process was to sift him, identify his weakness and strengths, let him in the inner circle, develop him etc and the final hours before Jesus’ crucifixion, Peter fails once again when he denies the Master three times. In as much as I believe Peter may have been impacted by the life of Christ, I believe what really impacted Peter was when Jesus, the Messiah whom they believed would come and restore the kingdom went to the cross and died for the sins of the world. Jesus said that He would destroy the temple and build it in three days referring to Himself. This I believe is one of the greatest episodes that transformed and revolutionized Peter, Romans 5:8, “But God demonstrates His own love toward us, in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.”. Sold out for the call.

Jesus resurrected and at some point three times asked Peter if he loved Him to me prove that Peter was ready for service. Peter had finally come through something tough, he had been in the fire of his own weakness and his own fears. He had held fast the scorching vision of Jesus’ death and understood it. Jesus dying for those who did not deserve His death for He was committed. In this, Peter had been restored to love and service by the mystery of Jesus resurrection. He could now understand that the vision they heard of who the Messiah was different from what they saw and experienced. Process progressed to transformation, ready for the Master’s use. Before Jesus left the earth he told them of the comforter and in, Acts 1:8, they were reminded of it “But you shall receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you;” Peter confession of his love for Christ and Christ instructions to him to feed His sheep brought him to a place where he sold himself out for the Lord. Peter was never the same again, receiving the power through the Holy Ghost marked the beginning of the fulfillment of Matthew 16:18. He became not only one of the most prominent of Jesus disciples but also later the leader and principle spokesman fledging Christian church. Afflictions awaited him but he would not retreat nor surrender for he was sold out to the point of death.

From the beginning it sounded like a position but now he understood it’s about humility and service. The bibles says in Philippians 2:7&8, But He (Christ) made Himself of no reputation, taking the form of a bondservant, coming in the likeness of man. …He humbled Himself and became obedient to the point of death, even the death of the cross”, Peter did the same, what he experienced could not be compared to what he would go through. I so pray that our weakness and failures would not dictate what we can be when He defines us and that we would be all be sold out to the Lord leaving no room for anything else but Christ Himself and to His service.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Sold Out For Jesus, Part 1

content.rendered:
Good morning,

Matthew 16:18, “And I also say to you that you are Peter, and on this rock I will build My church, and the gates of Hades shall not prevail against it”

Peter is one of my favorite characters in the bible for several reasons. He is the one who tries things that no one else tries, he says things that make you wonder where that came from. One minute he is strong, the next minute he is weak. He is quick to say things he cannot defend. He shows me of his spiritual side and his human side, his strength and weakness. He is one of Jesus disciples but also a friend let on the inner circle with all his faults. He rebuked Jesus when He spoke his death, he said he would not deny Jesus and he did. He did not want Jesus to wash his feet, he walked on the water and then doubted, he spoke of making tents for Jesus, Moses and Elijah when he had nothing else to say. I would get frustrated with such a person but he is a picture of what God cannot give up on. God knows how to take junk, make it and use it. If God was to give up on us the way we give up on people, we all would be in trouble. I’m amazed that He keeps on hanging to broken vessels that are not sold out ultimately that one day they will be whole.

This is a man who is not complete yet the Master is patient with him. The first thing that makes me believe He will be used mightily one day is when the Holy Sprit used him to define Jesus. Mathew 16:15, “He said to them, “But who do you say that I am?” 16, “Simon Peter answered and said, “You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.” 17,”Jesus answered and said to him, “Blessed are you, Simon Bar-Jonah, for flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but My Father who is in heaven“. In his faults and failures not even sold out, God uses him. God is not a respecter of any man but a respecter of principles. The first introduction to Peter, Matthew 16:18, “And I also say to you that you are Peter, and on this rock I will build My church, and the gates of Hades shall not prevail against it”. 19, “And I will give you the keys of the kingdom of heaven, and whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven.“. Jesus knew who He was, the definition Peter gave of Him by the help of the Holy Spirit was not to Jesus benefit but to the disciples who needed to truly know Him. Then Jesus defines Peter who wasn’t yet what he was defined but what Jesus had envisioned for his life. How can you be defined when you are not even there yet? He is told the gates of hell shall not prevail and the next minute, the gates of hell show up right after the words of the Lord cause Peter takes Jesus aside and rebukes Him when he talked about dying and what does Jesus do, “23, But He turned and said to Peter, “Get behind Me, Satan!”. How can this be? did Jesus make a mistake defining Peter and then he fails the next minute?. You can have a definition but not sold out yet!!!

Sold out is having all accommodations sold especially a head of time. Someone who is sold out for Jesus has no more room for anything that is not of Him. Many times we have faults like Peter and we call it a quit, the Master has not given up on us but we have given up on Him and ourselves. If Jesus would not dismiss Peter due to his nature, how do we expect to be dismissed? To continue, blessings Ev

Thanks

title.rendered: My Cares Are His Cares, Part 2

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Peter 5:6&7, “Humble yourselves therefore under the mighty hand of God, that He may exalt you in due season, casting all your cares upon Him, for He cares for you”

There is a praise song that blesses my heart I will tie to today’s message, “Oh most High, You are my stronghold; when troubles come, You are my hiding place; Oh most High, those who know You trust You; And You will not forsake the ones who seek Your face“. Those who know You Lord trust you with their cares for You will not forsake them.

Yesterday we looked at the Shunammite woman casting her cares by putting her dead son on the man of God’s bed and refusing to call it over until he came and certified that he was dead and that was it. She then embarks on a journey to find him and the man of God sends his servant, 2Kings 4:31, “Gehazi went on a head and laid the staff on the boy’s face, but there was no sound or response”. There are certain things I believe that will not happen until God does them Himself, hasn’t the word called Him Jehovah Shammah which means Jehovah present? and if that is not enough, Psalm 46:1 says, “God is our refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble” meaning He is ever present. In as much as Elisha’s servant had Elisha’s stuff to place on the boy, nothing happened and this tells us something about the presence of the man of God. The woman refused to let go of him until he made up his mind to come. We have an awesome opportunity to cast our cares upon Him through the journey of prayer in our search for Him. We seek first His Kingdom as we go an extra mile, lingering longer. He has found us but not we have to find Him though His presence is always with us. The word of the Lord says, “Call on me and I will answer you” Romans 10:13, “For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.”

2Kings 4:32, “When Elisha reached the house, there was the boy lying dead… vs. 33, “He went in, shut the door on the two of them and prayed to the Lord” vs. 34, “Then he got on the bed and laid upon the boy, mouth to mouth, eyes to eyes, hands to hands. As he stretched himself out upon him, the boy’s body grew warm” I praise God because everything that He does progresses from one stage to another and the more we linger longer in His presence the more His presence begins to make our cold body warm for not only does He capture our hearts, He captures our entire being. Acts 17:28, “For in Him we live, and move, and have our being; …”. Friends, the Lord cares not just for our souls but our entire being, He cares about what we go through, when we fail, He still cares for us, He cares about where we go, what we do, who we hang out with, what bothers us. He cares about all our needs, it’s now upon us to cast our cares on Him for He has demonstrated that He cares. He cared for this woman’s son that a prophet leaves everything he is doing to come to this woman’s rescue and when he comes, he takes the time to pray, stretch himself on the cold boy’s body until it becomes warm.

2Kings 4:35, “Elisha turned away and walked back and forth in the room and then got on the bed and stretched out upon him once more. The boy sneezed seven times and opened his eyes”. What a miracle, this miracle does not come the way many miracles came about. Many men of God spoke and the dead rose, on this one, the man prayed, stretched himself on the boy, walked back and forth praying and stretched himself on the boy once more. Got to have faith to believe that God can, so He will and the process may be different but for sure enough it will yield the same result. Seven is considered as the number of God, a number of perfection and for the little boy to sneeze seven times, he was being perfected for what God has done, can no man un do.

One woman learnt what it meant to cast her cares upon the Lord and the only way she could say, “It is well” was by giving God her cares to worry about. She had the faith in her distressing time, she trusted, she sought, encouraged herself. Can we reach to that level where instead of worrying, we can cast our cares upon Him. “Humble yourselves therefore under the mighty hand of God, that He may exalt you in due season, casting all your cares upon Him, for He cares for you”

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: My Care Are His Cares, Part 1

content.rendered:
Good morning,

1Peter 5:6&7, “Humble yourselves therefore under the mighty hand of God, that He may exalt you in due season, casting all your cares upon Him, for He cares for you”

Psalm 119:89 tell us that, “Forever Oh Lord, thy word is settled in heaven“, everything can change and will change but the word of God is forever settled (complete), God is the word Himself and so when we come to Him, we know for sure that He will perfect in us what He has began for no word will proceed from His mouth and return to Him void.

To make the above scripture more clear to us, let us revisit a familiar passage in the book of 2Kings 4. This is the story about a Shunammite woman. A woman who was so humble and kind that she went out of her way to take care Elisha anytime he was in town. The bible says, Humble yourselves therefore under the mighty hand of God something I saw in this woman’s life. One cannot bow and serve unless they are humbled and because of her humility and kindness, she received a prophesy that revealed a promise. 2Kings 4:16, “About this time next year, “Elisha said, “you will hold a son in your arms”. See how the verse above played part in this woman’s life, “that He may exalt you in due season”. It’s in her humility and kindness that opened doors for her to be exalted in due season. . The bible says that God does things in His own way and He makes all things beautiful in His time and when we all learn that everything He is doing them in His time, we have no room to try and rush or dictate Him for after it has been said and done, His timing will prevail. In as much as we want and desire things according to His will, they will not come in our timing, the marriages and relationships will not come in our timing, jobs and promotions will not also come in our timing and so is even ministry. We all got to reach to that place where we can humble ourselves even with the little knowing that He will exalt us in due season. Just because according to you, time is running out does not make God’s time run out. According to men standards, it was already too late for her to be blessed but we know that God always does the impossible that men may know He has the power to do so.

In the process of time, the Shunammite woman conceived the promised son and what a blessing it was for her and her husband. As the precious little boy was growing up and with the parents having visions and dreams for him, it happens that one day in vs. 18-, that the child complained of pain and later died on his mother’s laps. A fulfilled promised is snatched by death, hopes and dreams for the boy are shattered. Exalted in due season only for it to turn into a tragedy. What can she and her husband do? Some time ago I shared on “Don’t bury the dead yet“, this woman could have been quick to bury her son and so are we, we throw in the towel to quick, casting it a side because it’s not coming out like expected. You have cried and wept over it, it has taken your strength and confidence and all you are left with is regrets to have received the blessing in the first place. Your reaction when situations happens matters a lot, vs. 21, “She went up and laid him on the bed of the man of God, then shut the door and went out, vs. 22,”She called her husband and said, “Please send me one of the servants and a donkey so I can go to the man of God quickly and return”. We have looked at “humble yourself under the mighty hand of God”, we have also looked at “That He may exalt you in due season”, let’s now look at “casting all your cares upon Him“. She is casting all her cares upon the Lord by placing her dead child on the man of God’s bed and setting herself on a journey to find him. Yes I know that her trade mark in this passage is the fact that she can say, “It’s is well” but I see that she could not say these words unless she had cast her cares. She could have still held onto the dead child but that is not what she did, she gave it back to the Lord to certify that nothing else could be done and now she has the confidence to say it is well. You and I will find it hard to use these words as long as we are holding on to our cares. Holding onto your cares will steer you to worry, depression, confusion but the moment we give it to the Lord, you and I don’t need to worry about it anymore for our cares are in safe hands. Let God be the one to worry about it. I came across a joke a couple of years ago, a husband and wife are a sleep in bed, one day in the middle of the night, the husband wakes up and cant sleep tossing back and forth. The wife wakes up to find her worried husband smoking. So she asked him what the matter was and he explained to her that he was worried about how he was going to pay their next month’s rent. The wife gave him this advise, “Why don’t you call the landlord and let him be the one to worry about it instead of you”. We worry when we can do nothing about it, why not cast it upon the Lord for He cares for us.

Thanks
Evans

title.rendered: Tolerance, Part 2, By Charles T. Crabtree, Submitted by Phil the Evangelist

content.rendered:
Good morning
The apostle Paul showed us the proper use of tolerance in those things that were temporal and material. He must have been considered a liberal when he said, “I know, and am persuaded by the Lord Jesus, that there is nothing unclean of itself” (Romans 14:14). He was so tolerant of earthly things he could say, “I know both how to be abased, and I know how to abound” (Philippians 4:12).

Paul’s intolerance at any attempt to undermine the authority of Scripture and doctrine is well known. The first General Council in Jerusalem was to settle the role of circumcision and salvation. Paul’s intolerance of legalism kept Christ’s atonement and our salvation in the realm of faith–not works. This is the same apostle who wrote, “For as many as have sinned without law shall also perish without law” (Romans 2:12).

It does not take a great deal of spiritual acumen to ascertain the proper use of tolerance. Like loving mothers and fathers, we are tolerant and patient with our children in their normal growth and development. At the same time we are absolutely intolerant of anything or anyone who would harm them.

My prayer is that all will realize they have not been ordained by men to preach the gospel and declare the whole counsel of God. God has ordained and placed the mantle of divine authority upon His messengers. They are to be the purveyors of truth, not the secular press or unconverted, educated geniuses, or some Eastern guru.

It is my plea that every minister will fight the good fight of faith through a new emphasis on the apostles’ doctrine and Bible theology. Our task is to build people through the systematic teaching of the Word of God, not through a convoluted philosophy and false self-image. Our task is to make certain people know God, not just feel good.

“The fear of man bringeth a snare” (Proverbs 29:25). Nowhere is this truth more applicable than in this day when the world is demanding we be tolerant of all kinds of perversion and false doctrine. “For God hath not given us the spirit of fear; but of power, and of love, and of a sound mind” (2 Timothy 1:7).

What steps should be taken to withstand the strategy of Satan to destroy our faith and still the voice of truth?

    • Know your faith. “So then faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God” (Romans 10:17). Every believer, and especially every minister, needs to concentrate primarily on the Word of God and not on the words of men, even good men. Our faith grows as we eat food for faith. The renewal or addition to our faith is a daily discipline, not a weekly obligation.
    • Defend your faith. If you do not, who will? You are commanded by Scripture to “contend for the faith which was once delivered unto the saints” (Jude 3). The world may call you narrow-minded or bigoted or defensive, but that is not your problem; it is theirs. It is difficult not to appear defensive when you are defending. Do not be contentious in spirit or defensive in attitude, but be strong in your defense of the gosp
    • Declare your faith. The enemy would like nothing better than to still the testimony and witness of Pentecostal people. The apostle Paul would be a bit mystified by those who call themselves Christians but are afraid to share their faith. He said, “For I am not ashamed of the gospel of Christ: for it is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth” (Romans 1:16).

    Let us not allow the words of men to cancel the Word of God. Let us not let the spirit of the age overcome the indwelling Spirit of God. Let us not let the fear of men dissuade us from obedience to God. “For we preach not ourselves, but Christ Jesus the Lord” (2 Corinthians 4:5). “But though we, or an angel from heaven, preach any other gospel unto you than that which we have preached unto you, let him be accursed” (Galatians 1:8). That would be intolerable. Charles T. Crabtree is assistant general superintendent of the Assemblies of God, Springfield, Missouri.

title.rendered: Tolerance, Part 1, By Charles T. Crabtree, submitted by Phil the Evangelist

content.rendered:
Good morning
In the last few years, there has been great emphasis on spiritual warfare. A vast majority of Christian leaders would probably agree the focus on this subject is warranted. The New Testament uses militant language to describe our continuing battle with the enemy. Spiritual warfare is a biblical reality.

When a legitimate concern such as spiritual warfare is raised, there is an inherent danger–expending an inordinate amount of energy and focus on one front while neglecting an even greater threat on another.

A powerful enemy is a skillful enemy. He not only uses firepower, but also intellectual power. A master military strategist must be a master of deceit. Without question, Satan is a powerful enemy because he is a master in the use of illusion and deception.

One of the advantages the believer has against the devil is special insight beyond the obvious. Paul voiced this advantage in 2 Corinthians 2:11: “We are not ignorant of his devices.” The purpose of this article is to expose one of the devil’s most insidious strategies in the present spiritual conflict. It is the device called tolerance.

One of the most effective and destructive devices of Satan is the erroneous understanding and application of tolerance in our present culture. No church is unaffected by its corrosive influence. Satan is using tolerance to intimidate the preacher, undermine scriptural authority, and render the church of Jesus Christ helpless through negative propaganda. It is essential for all Christians to be forewarned and forearmed.

The devil is presently in the greatest disarmament program in history. His goal is to disarm the Church through brainwashing believers into thinking it is not Christian to defend their faith, be salt and light, and evangelize the world.

The satanic motivation behind the modern thrust of tolerance is rebellion against God’s authority. If the devil can diminish and destroy the authoritative Word of God in the minds of people, he will have accomplished his ultimate aim–to exalt himself above the throne of God.

In the Garden of Eden, Satan was planting the seeds of a demonically hybrid tolerance: “Hath God said…for God doth know…ye shall be as gods, knowing good and evil” (Genesis 3:1,5). In other words, there is no longer an absolute. Man is the source of his own truth. If it is evil to you, no problem; if it is good to you, no problem. Just do not interfere with what I think. We will not have any absolute authority over us telling us what is evil or what is good.

The enemy has made progress in his deceitful use of tolerance even within the Church. More and more I hear, “We are beyond doctrine,” or “I know we don’t believe the same things, but that shouldn’t keep us from having fellowship.” The lack of concern about what things we believe or do not believe is troublesome.

When someone says, “Doctrine divides,” I answer, “Of course, that is the nature of doctrine.” Doctrine is the formulation of the principles on which the Church bases its actions and policies. It is the basis of teaching and instruction. It is another term for revealed truth and, in the case of the Church, systematic theology.

The strategy of the enemy is to get the church of Jesus Christ involved in internal battles over nonessentials while meekly accepting poisoned K rations from the enemy. Some think spiritual warfare is contending for the traditions of the 1950s and 1960s while allowing eternal truth to die as the source of their spiritual lives and existence.

Jesus showed the proper use of tolerance throughout His earthly ministry: “Love your enemies, bless them that curse you, do good to them that hate you, and pray for them which despitefully use you, and persecute you” (Matthew 5:44). “Judge not, that ye be not judged” (Matthew 7:1). “He that is without sin among you, let him first cast a stone” (John 8:7). The list goes on and on.

The tolerance of Christ was supernatural in the realm of the physical and temporal, but His intolerance was supernatural in the realm of the spiritual and eternal. “I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me” (John 14:6). “I came not to send peace, but a sword” (Matthew 10:34). To continue
